{{Distinguish|Dual process theory}} The '''dual systems model''', also known as the '''maturational imbalance model''',<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Casey|first=B. J.|last2=Jones|first2=Rebecca M.|last3=Somerville|first3=Leah H.|date=2011-03-01|title=Braking and Accelerating of the Adolescent Brain|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1532-7795.2010.00712.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Research on Adolescence|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=21–33|doi=10.1111/j.1532-7795.2010.00712.x|issn=1532-7795|pmc=3070306}}</ref> is a theory arising from [[developmental cognitive neuroscience]] which posits that increased risk-taking during [[adolescence]] is a result of a combination of heightened reward sensitivity and immature [[Inhibitory control|impulse control]].<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Steinberg|first=Laurence|date=2010-04-01|title=A dual systems model of adolescent risk-taking|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/dev.20445/abstract|journal=Developmental Psychobiology|language=en|volume=52|issue=3|pages=216–224|doi=10.1002/dev.20445|issn=1098-2302}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Somerville|first=Leah H.|last2=Jones|first2=Rebecca M.|last3=Casey|first3=B.J.|title=A time of change: Behavioral and neural correlates of adolescent sensitivity to appetitive and aversive environmental cues|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0278262609001122|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=72|issue=1|pages=124–133|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2009.07.003|pmc=2814936}}</ref> In other words, the appreciation for the benefits arising from the success of an endeavor is heightened, but the appreciation of the risks of failure lags behind.
The dual systems model hypothesizes that early maturation of the socioemotional system (including brain regions like the [[striatum]]) increases adolescents' attraction for exciting, pleasurable, and novel activities during a time when cognitive control systems (including brain regions like the [[prefrontal cortex]]) are not fully developed and thus cannot regulate these appetitive, and potentially hazardous, impulses. The temporal gap in the development of the socioemotional and cognitive control systems creates a period of heightened vulnerability to risk-taking during mid-adolescence. In the dual systems model, "reward sensitivity" and "[[Executive functions|cognitive control]]" refer to neurobiological constructs that are measured in studies of brain structure and function. Other models similar to the dual systems model are the maturational imbalance model,<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Casey|first=B.j.|last2=Jones|first2=Rebecca M.|last3=Hare|first3=Todd A.|date=2008-03-01|title=The Adolescent Brain|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1196/annals.1440.010/abstract|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=1124|issue=1|pages=111–126|doi=10.1196/annals.1440.010|issn=1749-6632}}</ref> the driven dual systems model,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=http://content.apa.org/books/14643-005|title=Adolescent brain development: Implications for the juvenile criminal justice system.|last=Luna|first=Beatriz|last2=Wright|first2=Catherine|pages=91–116|language=en|doi=10.1037/14643-005}}</ref> and the triadic model.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Ernst|first=Monique|title=The triadic model perspective for the study of adolescent motivated behavior|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0278262614000086|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=89|pages=104–111|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2014.01.006}}</ref>
== Historical perspective == The dual systems model arose out of evidence from developmental cognitive neuroscience providing insight into how patterns of brain development could explain aspects of adolescent decision-making. In 2008, [[Laurence Steinberg]]'s laboratory at [[Temple University]] and BJ Casey's laboratory at [[Cornell University|Cornell]] separately proposed similar dual systems theories of adolescent risky decision-making.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Steinberg|first=Laurence|date=2008|title=A Social Neuroscience Perspective on Adolescent Risk-Taking|journal=Developmental review : DR|volume=28|issue=1|pages=78–106|doi=10.1016/j.dr.2007.08.002|issn=0273-2297|pmc=2396566|pmid=18509515|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Steinberg|first=Laurence|last2=Albert|first2=Dustin|last3=Cauffman|first3=Elizabeth|last4=Banich|first4=Marie|last5=Graham|first5=Sandra|last6=Woolard|first6=Jennifer|title=Age differences in sensation seeking and impulsivity as indexed by behavior and self-report: Evidence for a dual systems model.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0012955|journal=Developmental Psychology|language=en|volume=44|issue=6|pages=1764–1778|doi=10.1037/a0012955}}</ref> Casey et al. termed their model the maturational imbalance model.{{cn|date=August 2018}}
== Models == [[File:Models of Adolescent Brain Development.png|thumb|482x482px|Development of the socioemotional and cognitive control systems as depicted by the dual systems model, maturational imbalance model, and driven dual systems model]]
=== Maturational imbalance model === Both the dual systems model and the maturational imbalance model conceive of a slower developing cognitive control system that matures through late adolescence. The dual systems model proposes an inverted-U shape development of the socioemotional system, such that reward responsivity increases in early adolescence and declines thereafter. The maturational imbalance model portrays a socioemotional system that reaches its peak around mid-adolescence and then plateaus into adulthood. Further, the dual systems model proposes that the development of the cognitive control and socioemotional systems is independent whereas the maturational imbalance proposes that the maturation of the cognitive control system leads to dampening of socioemotional responsivity.<ref name=":16" /><ref name=":17" />
=== Driven dual systems model === Recently, another variation of the dual systems model was proposed called the "driven dual systems model".<ref name=":1" /> This model proposes an inverted-U shaped trajectory of socioemotional system responsivity, similar to the dual systems model, but hypothesizes a cognitive control trajectory that plateaus in mid-adolescence. This cognitive control trajectory differs from that proposed by the dual systems model and maturational imbalance model which continues to increase into the early 20s. Similar to the driven dual systems model, a model has been proposed including a hyperactive socioemotional system that undermines the regulatory ability of the cognitive control system.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Luciana|first=Monica|last2=Collins|first2=Paul F.|date=2012-12-01|title=Incentive Motivation, Cognitive Control, and the Adolescent Brain: Is It Time for a Paradigm Shift?|journal=Child Development Perspectives|volume=6|issue=4|pages=392–399|doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2012.00252.x|issn=1750-8592|pmc=3607661|pmid=23543860}}</ref> These later models hypothesize that cognitive control development is completed by mid-adolescence and attribute increased risk-taking during adolescence to the hyperarousal of the socioemotional system. The dual systems model and maturational imbalance model propose that cognitive control development continues into early adulthood and that increased risk-taking in adolescence is attributable to a developmental imbalance where the socioemotional system is at its peak of development but the cognitive control system developmental trajectory lags behind.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Shulman|first=Elizabeth P.|last2=Smith|first2=Ashley R.|last3=Silva|first3=Karol|last4=Icenogle|first4=Grace|last5=Duell|first5=Natasha|last6=Chein|first6=Jason|last7=Steinberg|first7=Laurence|title=The dual systems model: Review, reappraisal, and reaffirmation|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1878929315001292|journal=Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=17|pages=103–117|doi=10.1016/j.dcn.2015.12.010}}</ref>
=== Triadic model === The "triadic model", which includes a third brain system responsible for emotion processing and primarily implicating the [[amygdala]].<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=ERNST|first=MONIQUE|last2=PINE|first2=DANIEL S.|last3=HARDIN|first3=MICHAEL|date=2006|title=Triadic model of the neurobiology of motivated behavior in adolescence|journal=Psychological medicine|volume=36|issue=3|pages=299–312|doi=10.1017/S0033291705005891|issn=0033-2917|pmc=2733162|pmid=16472412|via=}}</ref> The triadic model proposes that this emotion system increases [[impulsivity]] during adolescence by increasing the perceived cost of delaying [[decision-making]]. This model posits that impulsivity and risk seeking in adolescence is due to a combination of hyperactive reward systems causing adolescents to approach appetitive stimuli, emotion processing systems causing adolescents to enhance perceived costs of delaying behaviors and reduce avoidance of potentially negative stimuli, and an underdeveloped cognitive control system that is unable to regulate reward-seeking behaviors.<ref name=":18" />
== Adolescent risk-taking == Risk-taking in certain, but not all, domains peaks during adolescence. Most notably, [[Mortality rate|mortality]] and [[morbidity]] rates increase significantly from childhood to adolescence<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=Ronald E.|date=June 2004|title=Adolescent brain development: a period of vulnerabilities and opportunities. Keynote address|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=1021|pages=1–22|doi=10.1196/annals.1308.001|issn=0077-8923|pmid=15251869}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Casey|first=B. J.|last2=Caudle|first2=Kristina|date=2013-04-16|title=The Teenage Brain|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0963721413480170|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|language=en|volume=22|issue=2|pages=82–87|doi=10.1177/0963721413480170}}</ref> despite the fact that physical and mental capabilities increase during this period. The primary cause for this increase in mortality/morbidity among adolescents is preventable injury. According to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Center for Disease Control,]] in 2014 about 40% of all adolescent deaths (ages 15–19 years) were caused by unintentional accidents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr65/nvsr65_05.pdf|title=Deaths: Leading Causes for 2014|last=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|first=|date=June 30, 2016|website=www.cdc.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> From 1999 to 2006, almost one-half of all adolescent deaths (ages 12–19 years) were due to accidental injury.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/databriefs/db37.htm|title=Mortality Among Teenagers Aged 12-19 Years: United States, 1999-2006|last=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|first=|date=May 2010|website=www.cdc.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Of these unintentional injuries, about 2/3 are due to [[Traffic collision|motor vehicle accidents]], followed by unintentional [[poisoning]], unintentional [[drowning]], other land transportation accidents, and unintentional discharge of firearms.<ref name=":3" />
The dual systems model proposes that mid-adolescence is the time of highest biological propensity for risk-taking, but that older adolescents may exhibit higher levels of real-world risk-taking (e.g., [[binge drinking]] is most common during the early 20s)<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470479193.adlpsy001022/abstract|title=Handbook of Adolescent Psychology|last=Chassin|first=Laurie|last2=Hussong|first2=Andrea|last3=Beltran|first3=Iris|date=2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|isbn=9780470479193|language=en|doi=10.1002/9780470479193.adlpsy001022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Willoughby|first=Teena|last2=Good|first2=Marie|last3=Adachi|first3=Paul J.C.|last4=Hamza|first4=Chloe|last5=Tavernier|first5=Royette|title=Examining the link between adolescent brain development and risk taking from a social–developmental perspective|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0278262613001437|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=83|issue=3|pages=315–323|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2013.09.008}}</ref> not due to greater propensity for risk-taking but due to greater opportunity.<ref name=":2" /> For example, individuals in their early 20s compared to mid-adolescence have less adult supervision, greater financial resources, and greater legal privileges. The dual systems model looks to experimental paradigms in developmental neuroscience for evidence of this greater biological propensity for risk-taking.<ref name=":17" />
There is also a consistent relation between age and crime with adolescents and young adults being more likely to engage in violent and non-violent crime.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Steinberg|first=L|date=2013|title=The influence of neuroscience on US Supreme Court decisions about adolescents' criminal culpability.|url=|journal=Nat. Rev. Neurosci.|volume=14|pages=513–518|via=}}</ref> These findings are linked to increases in [[Sensation seeking|sensation-seeking]], which is the tendency to seek out novel, exciting, and rewarding stimuli, during adolescence, and continued development of impulse control, which is the ability to regulate one's behavior. The dual systems model points to brain development as a mechanism for this association.<ref name=":17" />

Sensation-seeking is a type of reward seeking involving the tendency to seek out novel, exciting, and rewarding stimuli. Sensation-seeking has been found to increase in preadolescence, peak in mid-adolescence, and decline in early adulthood.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Harden|first=K. Paige|last2=Tucker-Drob|first2=Elliot M.|title=Individual differences in the development of sensation seeking and impulsivity during adolescence: Further evidence for a dual systems model|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0023279|journal=Developmental Psychology|language=en|volume=47|issue=3|pages=739–746|doi=10.1037/a0023279}}</ref>
=== Impulsivity === Impulsivity has been found to exhibit a different developmental trajectory than reward or sensation seeking.<ref name=":4" /> Impulsivity gradually declines with age in a [[Linearity|linear]] fashion.<ref name="Galvan F8–F14">{{Cite journal|last=Galvan|first=Adriana|last2=Hare|first2=Todd|last3=Voss|first3=Henning|last4=Glover|first4=Gary|last5=Casey|first5=B. J.|date=March 2007|title=Risk-taking and the adolescent brain: who is at risk?|journal=Developmental Science|volume=10|issue=2|pages=F8–F14|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2006.00579.x|issn=1363-755X|pmid=17286837}}</ref> Around mid-adolescence when impulsivity and sensation-seeking are at their peak is the theoretical peak age for risk-taking according to the dual systems model.<ref name=":17" />
=== Social influence === Adolescent risk-taking is more likely to occur in the presence of peers compared to adults.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Simons-Morton|first=Bruce|last2=Lerner|first2=Neil|last3=Singer|first3=Jeremiah|date=November 2005|title=The observed effects of teenage passengers on the risky driving behavior of teenage drivers|journal=Accident; Analysis and Prevention|volume=37|issue=6|pages=973–982|doi=10.1016/j.aap.2005.04.014|issn=0001-4575|pmid=15921652}}</ref> Animal studies have found that adolescent mice, but not adult mice, consume more alcohol in the presence of peers than when alone.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Logue|first=Sheree|last2=Chein|first2=Jason|last3=Gould|first3=Thomas|last4=Holliday|first4=Erica|last5=Steinberg|first5=Laurence|date=January 2014|title=Adolescent Mice, Unlike Adults, Consume More Alcohol in the Presence of Peers than Alone|journal=Developmental science|volume=17|issue=1|doi=10.1111/desc.12101|issn=1363-755X|pmc=3869041|pmid=24341974}}</ref> In humans, the presence of peers has been found to result in increased activation in the [[striatum]] and [[orbitofrontal cortex]] risk-taking, and activation in these regions predicted subsequent risk-taking among adolescents but not adults.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Chein|first=Jason|last2=Albert|first2=Dustin|last3=O'Brien|first3=Lia|last4=Uckert|first4=Kaitlyn|last5=Steinberg|first5=Laurence|date=2011-03-01|title=Peers increase adolescent risk taking by enhancing activity in the brain's reward circuitry|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-7687.2010.01035.x/abstract|journal=Developmental Science|language=en|volume=14|issue=2|pages=F1–F10|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2010.01035.x|issn=1467-7687}}</ref> Age differences in activation of the striatum and [[Frontal lobe|frontal cortex]] have been interpreted to suggest heightened risk-taking in the presence of peers is due to the influence of peers on reward processing rather than the influence of peers on cognitive control.<ref name=":6" />
== Socioemotional system == The term socioemotional brain network or system (also known as the ventral affective system) refers to the striatum as well as the medial and orbital [[Prefrontal cortex|prefrontal cortices]].<ref name="Pfeifer2012">{{cite journal|last1=Pfeifer|first1=Jennifer H.|last2=Peake|first2=Shannon J.|year=2012|title=Self-development: Integrating cognitive, socioemotional, and neuroimaging perspectives|journal=Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=2|issue=1|pages=55–69|issn=1878-9293|doi=10.1016/j.dcn.2011.07.012}}</ref>
=== Dopamine === Evidence from [[animal testing on rodents|rodent studies]] indicates the [[Dopamine|dopaminergic system]], the pathway connecting the [[ventral tegmental area]] to the [[nucleus accumbens]] and [[olfactory tubercle]], plays a critical role in the brain's reward circuitry and the dopamine-rich striatum has been implicated as a key contributor to reward sensitivity in the brain.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schultz|first=W.|date=July 1998|title=Predictive reward signal of dopamine neurons|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|volume=80|issue=1|pages=1–27|issn=0022-3077|pmid=9658025}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Montague|first=P. Read|last2=Hyman|first2=Steven E.|last3=Cohen|first3=Jonathan D.|date=2004-10-14|title=Computational roles for dopamine in behavioural control|journal=Nature|volume=431|issue=7010|pages=760–767|doi=10.1038/nature03015|issn=1476-4687|pmid=15483596}}</ref>
During puberty, the dopaminergic system undergoes significant reorganization.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Spear|first=L. P.|date=June 2000|title=The adolescent brain and age-related behavioral manifestations|journal=Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|volume=24|issue=4|pages=417–463|issn=0149-7634|pmid=10817843}}</ref> Increased dopamine projections from [[Mesolimbic pathway|mesolimbic]] areas (e.g., the striatum) to the prefrontal cortex<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teicher|first=M. H.|last2=Andersen|first2=S. L.|last3=Hostetter|first3=J. C.|date=1995-11-21|title=Evidence for dopamine receptor pruning between adolescence and adulthood in striatum but not nucleus accumbens|journal=Brain Research. These projections are pruned decline in early adulthood.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doremus-Fitzwater|first=Tamara L.|last2=Varlinskaya|first2=Elena I.|last3=Spear|first3=Linda P.|date=February 2010|title=Motivational systems in adolescence: possible implications for age differences in substance abuse and other risk-taking behaviors|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=72|issue=1|pages=114–123|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2009.08.008|issn=1090-2147|pmc=2814912|pmid=19762139}}</ref> Adolescent-specific peaks in dopamine receptors in the striatum have been observed in humans and rodents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wahlstrom|first=Dustin|last2=White|first2=Tonya|last3=Luciana|first3=Monica|date=April 2010|title=Neurobehavioral evidence for changes in dopamine system activity during adolescence|journal=Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|volume=34|issue=5|pages=631–648|doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2009.12.007|issn=1873-7528|pmc=2845533|pmid=20026110}}</ref> Additionally, dopamine concentrations projecting to the prefrontal cortex increase into adolescence as do the dopamine projections from the prefrontal cortex to the striatum (namely the nucleus accumbens).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brenhouse|first=Heather C.|last2=Andersen|first2=Susan L.|date=August 2011|title=Developmental trajectories during adolescence in males and females: a cross-species understanding of underlying brain changes|journal=Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|volume=35|issue=8|pages=1687–1703|doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2011.04.013|issn=0149-7634|pmc=3134153|pmid=21600919}}</ref>
=== Hyper- versus hypo-sensitivity to reward === The striatum has been linked to reward processing, learning, and motivation.{{refn|<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ernst|first=Monique|last2=Pine|first2=Daniel S.|last3=Hardin|first3=Michael|date=March 2006|title=Triadic model of the neurobiology of motivated behavior in adolescence|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/psychological-medicine/article/triadic-model-of-the-neurobiology-of-motivated-behavior-in-adolescence/60D7FAB8086D4E84A61292680F663F32|journal=Psychological Medicine|volume=36|issue=3|pages=299–312|doi=10.1017/s0033291705005891|issn=1469-8978}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Galvan|first=Adriana|last2=Hare|first2=Todd A.|last3=Parra|first3=Cindy E.|last4=Penn|first4=Jackie|last5=Voss|first5=Henning|last6=Glover|first6=Gary|last7=Casey|first7=B. ==== Hyperactivity ==== Neuroimaging studies using [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] (fMRI) have shown that the ventral striatum is more active among adolescents compared to children and adults when receiving monetary rewards,<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Van Leijenhorst|first=Linda|last2=Zanolie|first2=Kiki|last3=Van Meel|first3=Catharina S.|last4=Westenberg|first4=P. ==== Hypoactivity ==== Some studies have found that striatum activity is blunted compared to children and adults when anticipating rewards,<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Bjork|first=James M.|last2=Knutson|first2=Brian|last3=Fong|first3=Grace W.|last4=Caggiano|first4=Daniel M.|last5=Bennett|first5=Shannon M.|last6=Hommer|first6=Daniel W.|date=2004-02-25|title=Incentive-elicited brain activation in adolescents: similarities and differences from young adults|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|volume=24|issue=8|pages=1793–1802|doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4862-03.2004|issn=1529-2401|pmid=14985419}}</ref> which has been linked to greater risk-taking behaviors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schneider|first=Sophia|last2=Peters|first2=Jan|last3=Bromberg|first3=Uli|last4=Brassen|first4=Stefanie|last5=Miedl|first5=Stephan F.|last6=Banaschewski|first6=Tobias|last7=Barker|first7=Gareth J.|last8=Conrod|first8=Patricia|last9=Flor|first9=Herta|date=January 2012|title=Risk taking and the adolescent reward system: a potential common link to substance abuse|journal=The American Journal of Psychiatry|volume=169|issue=1|pages=39–46|doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.2011.11030489|issn=1535-7228|pmid=21955931}}</ref> The theory linking this hypoactivation to greater risk-taking is that adolescents experience less gratifying experience from anticipating rewards and they are therefore motivated to seek out more reward-inducing experiences to achieve the same level of reward sensation as other age groups.<ref name=":10" />
==== Current consensus ==== Although evidence exists for both adolescent hyper-responsiveness to rewards and hypo-responsiveness to rewards, the field of [[Developmental cognitive neuroscience|developmental neuroscience]] has generally converged on the view of hyper-responsiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Galvan|first=Adriana|date=2010-02-12|title=Adolescent Development of the Reward System|journal=Frontiers in Human Neuroscience|volume=4|doi=10.3389/neuro.09.006.2010|issn=1662-5161|pmc=2826184|pmid=20179786}}</ref> In other words, that is, that adolescents are motivated, in part, to engage in greater reward-seeking behaviors because of developmental changes in the striatum that contribute to hypersensitivity to reward.<ref name=":7" />
== Cognitive control system == The cognitive control system refers to the lateral prefrontal, lateral parietal, and anterior cingulate cortices. The most commonly investigated region is the prefrontal cortex which undergoes substantial development throughout adolescence.<ref name=":11" /> The development of the prefrontal cortex has been implicated in the ability to regulate behavior and engage in inhibitory control.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Paus|first=Tomás|date=February 2005|title=Mapping brain maturation and cognitive development during adolescence|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume=9|issue=2|pages=60–68|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2004.12.008|issn=1364-6613|pmid=15668098}}</ref>
As a result of synaptic pruning and myelination of the prefrontal cortex, improvements in executive functions have been observed during adolescence.<ref name=":19" />
=== Synaptic pruning === During development, the brain undergoes overproduction of [[neuron]]s and their [[Synaptic pruning|synaptic]] connections and then prunes those that are unnecessary for optimal functioning.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huttenlocher|first=P. R.|last2=Dabholkar|first2=A. S.|date=1997-10-20|title=Regional differences in synaptogenesis in human cerebral cortex|journal=The Journal of Comparative Neurology|volume=387|issue=2|pages=167–178|issn=0021-9967|pmid=9336221}}</ref> This developmental process results in [[grey matter]] reduction over development. During adolescence, this pruning process is specialized with some areas losing approximately half of their synaptic connections but others showing little change.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Gogtay|first=Nitin|last2=Giedd|first2=Jay N.|last3=Lusk|first3=Leslie|last4=Hayashi|first4=Kiralee M.|last5=Greenstein|first5=Deanna|last6=Vaituzis|first6=A. Catherine|last7=Nugent|first7=Tom F.|last8=Herman|first8=David H.|last9=Clasen|first9=Liv S.|date=2004-05-25|title=Dynamic mapping of human cortical development during childhood through early adulthood|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=101|issue=21|pages=8174–8179|doi=10.1073/pnas.0402680101|issn=0027-8424|pmid=15148381}}</ref> Total grey matter volume undergoes substantial [[Synaptic pruning|pruning]] starting around [[puberty]]. The process of grey matter loss (i.e., maturation) occurs differentially in different brain regions with frontal and [[Occipital lobe|occipital]] poles losing grey matter early, but the prefrontal cortex losing grey matter only at the end of adolescence.<ref name=":14" />
=== Myelination === In addition to synaptic pruning, the brain undergoes [[myelin]]ation, which influences the speed of information flow across brain regions. Myelination involves neuronal [[axon]]s connecting certain brain areas to become insulated with a white, fatty substance called myelin that increases the speed and efficiency of transmission along axons. Myelination increases dramatically during adolescence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paus|first=Tomáš|title=Growth of white matter in the adolescent brain: Myelin or axon?|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0278262609001006|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=72|issue=1|pages=26–35|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2009.06.002}}</ref> Myelination contributes to the developmental thinning or reduction in grey matter in the prefrontal cortex during adolescence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tau|first=Gregory Z.|last2=Peterson|first2=Bradley S.|date=January 2010|title=Normal development of brain circuits|journal=Neuropsychopharmacology|volume=35|issue=1|pages=147–168|doi=10.1038/npp.2009.115|issn=1740-634X|pmc=3055433|pmid=19794405}}</ref>
=== Links to inhibitory control === Evidence supporting the dual systems model theory of delayed maturation of the cognitive control system is supported by evidence of structural changes like cortical thinning<ref name=":14" /> as well as less diffuse activation of frontal regions during inhibitory control tasks from adolescence to adulthood.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Casey|first=B. J.|last2=Trainor|first2=R. J.|last3=Orendi|first3=J. L.|last4=Schubert|first4=A. B.|last5=Nystrom|first5=L. E.|last6=Giedd|first6=J. N.|last7=Castellanos|first7=F. X.|last8=Haxby|first8=J. V.|last9=Noll|first9=D. C.|date=November 1997|title=A Developmental Functional MRI Study of Prefrontal Activation during Performance of a Go-No-Go Task|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=9|issue=6|pages=835–847|doi=10.1162/jocn.1997.9.6.835|issn=0898-929X|pmid=23964603}}</ref><ref name="Durston 1–8">{{Cite journal|last=Durston|first=Sarah|last2=Davidson|first2=Matthew C.|last3=Tottenham|first3=Nim|last4=Galvan|first4=Adriana|last5=Spicer|first5=Julie|last6=Fossella|first6=John A.|last7=Casey|first7=B. J.|date=January 2006|title=A shift from diffuse to focal cortical activity with development|journal=Developmental Science|volume=9|issue=1|pages=1–8|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2005.00454.x|issn=1363-755X|pmid=16445387}}</ref> Regardless of age, increased activation of the prefrontal cortex is related to better performance on response inhibition tasks.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ridderinkhof|first=K. Richard|last2=Wildenberg|first2=Wery P.M. van den|last3=Segalowitz|first3=Sidney J.|last4=Carter|first4=Cameron S.|title=Neurocognitive mechanisms of cognitive control: The role of prefrontal cortex in action selection, response inhibition, performance monitoring, and reward-based learning|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0278262604002866|journal=Brain and Cognition|volume=56|issue=2|pages=129–140|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2004.09.016}}</ref>
== Experimental paradigms == {{Off topic|date=July 2018}} === Reward tasks === Three primary [[Experiment|experimental paradigms]] are used to study reward behavior in adolescents (1) passive receipt of reward, (2) reward conditional on task performance, and (3) decision-making selecting different types of reward options.
==== Passive exposure tasks ==== Passive exposure tasks generally involve exposing the participant to pleasant stimuli (e.g., monetary reward, attractive faces). These paradigms also involve exposure to negative stimuli for the purposes of comparison (e.g., monetary loss, angry faces). Although these tasks are more commonly used to investigate emotion processing rather than reward, some studies have used a slot-machine passive task<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Van Leijenhorst|first=Linda|last2=Moor|first2=Bregtje Gunther|last3=Macks|first3=Zdeňa A. Op de|last4=Rombouts|first4=Serge A.R.B.|last5=Westenberg|first5=P. Michiel|last6=Crone|first6=Eveline A.|title=Adolescent risky decision-making: Neurocognitive development of reward and control regions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1053811910002065|journal=NeuroImage|volume=51|issue=1|pages=345–355|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.02.038}}</ref> to target reward circuitry in the brain. Faces have also been used as reward for motivational paradigms.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kohls|first=Gregor|last2=Schulte-Rüther|first2=Martin|last3=Nehrkorn|first3=Barbara|last4=Müller|first4=Kristin|last5=Fink|first5=Gereon R.|last6=Kamp-Becker|first6=Inge|last7=Herpertz-Dahlmann|first7=Beate|last8=Schultz|first8=Robert T.|last9=Konrad|first9=Kerstin|date=June 2013|title=Reward system dysfunction in autism spectrum disorders|journal=Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience|volume=8|issue=5|pages=565–572|doi=10.1093/scan/nss033|issn=1749-5016|pmc=3682440|pmid=22419119}}</ref> Passive exposure tasks have been found to activate the striatum and orbitofrontal cortex, with striatal activation greater in adolescents in response to rewarding stimuli but orbitofrontal activation greater in adults in response to negative stimuli.<ref name=":15" />
==== Performance contingent tasks ==== Reward tied to task performance typically involves participants being asked to complete a task in order to obtain a reward (and sometimes to avoid losing a reward). Task performance is not necessarily directly related to the reward. Examples of this type of task are the Pirate's paradigm,<ref name=":11" /> monetary incentive delay (MID) task,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Knutson|first=B.|last2=Adams|first2=C. M.|last3=Fong|first3=G. W.|last4=Hommer|first4=D.|date=2001-08-15|title=Anticipation of increasing monetary reward selectively recruits nucleus accumbens|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|volume=21|issue=16|pages=RC159|issn=1529-2401|pmid=11459880}}</ref> [[Iowa gambling task|Iowa Gambling Task]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bechara|first=A.|last2=Damasio|first2=A. R.|last3=Damasio|first3=H.|last4=Anderson|first4=S. W.|date=April 1994|title=Insensitivity to future consequences following damage to human prefrontal cortex|journal=Cognition|volume=50|issue=1-3|pages=7–15|issn=0010-0277|pmid=8039375}}</ref> Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART),<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lejuez|first=C. W.|last2=Read|first2=Jennifer P.|last3=Kahler|first3=Christopher W.|last4=Richards|first4=Jerry B.|last5=Ramsey|first5=Susan E.|last6=Stuart|first6=Gregory L.|last7=Strong|first7=David R.|last8=Brown|first8=Richard A.|date=June 2002|title=Evaluation of a behavioral measure of risk taking: the Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART)|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology. Applied|volume=8|issue=2|pages=75–84|issn=1076-898X|pmid=12075692}}</ref> and Columbia Card Task,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Figner, Voelki|first=|date=2004|title=Risky decision making in a computer card game: An information integration experiment.|url=|journal=Polish Psychological Bulletin|volume=35|pages=135–139|via=}}</ref> among others. Differences in activation to anticipation of reward versus preparation to try and achieve reward have been reported on performance related reward tasks.<ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" />
==== Decision-making tasks ==== Reward decision-making tasks involve participants being asked to choose among different options of reward. Sometimes the rewards differ on [[probability]], magnitude, or type of reward (e.g., social versus monetary). These tasks are typically conceived to not have a correct or incorrect response, but rather to have decision-making based on the participants' preference. Examples of decision making tasks include delay discounting tasks<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Christakou|first=Anastasia|last2=Brammer|first2=Mick|last3=Rubia|first3=Katya|date=2011-01-15|title=Maturation of limbic corticostriatal activation and connectivity associated with developmental changes in temporal discounting|journal=NeuroImage|volume=54|issue=2|pages=1344–1354|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.08.067|issn=1095-9572|pmid=20816974}}</ref> and the Driving Game.<ref name=":6" /> During feedback on decision-making tasks, greater striatal activation to rewarding outcomes has been observed in adolescents compared to adults.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":15" />
=== Response inhibition tasks === Common response inhibition tasks are the Go/No-Go, [[Eriksen flanker task|Flanker]], [[Stroop effect|Stroop]], Stop Signal, and [[Antisaccade task|anti-saccade]] tasks. Individuals who perform well on these tasks generally activate the prefrontal cortex to a greater extent than individuals who perform poorly on these tasks.<ref name="Durston 1–8"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rubia|first=Katya|last2=Smith|first2=Anna B.|last3=Woolley|first3=James|last4=Nosarti|first4=Chiara|last5=Heyman|first5=Isobel|last6=Taylor|first6=Eric|last7=Brammer|first7=Mick|date=December 2006|title=Progressive increase of frontostriatal brain activation from childhood to adulthood during event-related tasks of cognitive control|journal=Human Brain Mapping|volume=27|issue=12|pages=973–993|doi=10.1002/hbm.20237|issn=1065-9471|pmid=16683265}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rubia|first=Katya|last2=Lim|first2=Lena|last3=Ecker|first3=Christine|last4=Halari|first4=Rozmin|last5=Giampietro|first5=Vincent|last6=Simmons|first6=Andrew|last7=Brammer|first7=Michael|last8=Smith|first8=Anna|title=Effects of age and gender on neural networks of motor response inhibition: From adolescence to mid-adulthood|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1053811913007210|journal=NeuroImage|volume=83|pages=690–703|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2013.06.078}}</ref> Performance on these tasks improves with age.
==== Go/No-Go task ==== The Go/No-Go task requires participants to respond, usually by pressing a button or a key on a computer keyboard, to a designated cue or withhold a response, by not pressing the button/key, to a different designated cue. Variants of this task include [[alphabet]] letters, shapes, and faces.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tashjian|first=Sarah M.|last2=Goldenberg|first2=Diane|last3=Galván|first3=Adriana|title=Neural connectivity moderates the association between sleep and impulsivity in adolescents|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1878929317301111|journal=Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=27|pages=35–44|doi=10.1016/j.dcn.2017.07.006}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tottenham|first=Nim|last2=Hare|first2=Todd A.|last3=Casey|first3=B. J.|date=2011|title=Behavioral Assessment of Emotion Discrimination, Emotion Regulation, and Cognitive Control in Childhood, Adolescence, and Adulthood|url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2011.00039/abstract|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|language=English|volume=2|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2011.00039|issn=1664-1078}}</ref>
==== Flanker task ==== The [[Eriksen flanker task|Flanker]] task typically involves presentation of a target flanked by non-target stimuli that is either in the same direction as the target (congruent) or in the opposite direction of a target (incongruent) or neither direction (neutral). Participants have to respond to the direction of the target ignoring the non-target stimuli.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Verbruggen|first=Frederick|last2=Notebaert|first2=Wim|last3=Liefooghe|first3=Baptist|last4=Vandierendonck|first4=André|date=2006-04-01|title=Stimulus- and response-conflict-induced cognitive control in the flanker task|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/BF03193852|journal=Psychonomic Bulletin & Review|language=en|volume=13|issue=2|pages=328–333|doi=10.3758/bf03193852|issn=1069-9384}}</ref>
==== Stroop tasks ==== [[Stroop effect|Stroop]] tasks require participants to respond to one facet of the presented stimuli (e.g., read the word) but ignore another competing facet (e.g., ignore a contradictory color).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Klopfer|first=Dale S.|date=2016-05-06|title=Stroop Interference and Color-Word Similarity|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9280.1996.tb00348.x|journal=Psychological Science|language=en|volume=7|issue=3|pages=150–157|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.1996.tb00348.x}}</ref>
==== Stop signal task ==== The Stop Signal task is similar to the Go/No-Go task in that participants see a cue indicating a go trial. For stop trials, participants see the go cue but then are presented with the stop signal (typically a sound) indicating they should not respond to the go trial. Presenting the stop signal after the go cue makes this task more difficult than traditional Go/No-Go tasks.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnstone|first=Stuart J.|last2=Dimoska|first2=Aneta|last3=Smith|first3=Janette L.|last4=Barry|first4=Robert J.|last5=Pleffer|first5=Carly B.|last6=Chiswick|first6=Dale|last7=Clarke|first7=Adam R.|title=The development of stop-signal and Go/Nogo response inhibition in children aged 7–12 years: Performance and event-related potential indices|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0167876006002054|journal=International Journal of Psychophysiology|volume=63|issue=1|pages=25–38|doi=10.1016/j.ijpsycho.2006.07.001}}</ref>
==== Anti-saccade task ==== [[Antisaccade task|Anti-saccade]] tasks typically require participants to fixate on a motionless target. A stimulus is then presented on one side of the target and the participant is asked to make a saccade (either move their eyes or respond with a button press) in the direction away from the stimulus.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Unsworth|first=Nash|last2=Schrock|first2=Josef C.|last3=Engle|first3=Randall W.|title=Working Memory Capacity and the Antisaccade Task: Individual Differences in Voluntary Saccade Control.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/0278-7393.30.6.1302|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|language=en|volume=30|issue=6|pages=1302–1321|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.30.6.1302}}</ref>
== Legal relevance == Adolescent developmental immaturity and culpability were central to three [[Supreme Court of the United States|US Supreme Court]] cases: ''[[Roper v. Simmons]]'',<ref>Roper v. Simmons 543 U.S. 551 (2005)</ref> ''[[Graham v. Florida]]'',<ref>Graham v. Florida, 560 U.S. 48 (2010)</ref> and [[Miller v. Alabama|''Miller v.'' ''Alabama'']].<ref name=":20">Miller v. Alabama, 567 U.S. 460 (2012)</ref> Prior to ''Roper'' in 2005, the Supreme Court had relied on common sense standards to determine adolescent culpability. For example, in ''[[Thompson v. Oklahoma]]'',<ref name=":21">Thompson v. Oklahoma, 487 U.S. 815 (1988)</ref> the Court prohibited capital punishment for individuals under the age of 16 stating that "Contemporary standards of decency confirm our judgment that such a young person is not capable of acting with the degree of culpability that can justify the ultimate penalty."<ref name=":21" /> In ''Roper'', however, the Court looked to developmental science as rationale for abolishing [[capital punishment]] for [[Juvenile delinquency|juveniles]]. In 2010, the Court ruled life without parole was unconstitutional for juveniles in ''Graham'' and in 2012 the Court ruled that States could not mandate life without parole for juveniles even in the case of homicide in ''Miller.'' In ''Miller'', the Court stated "It is increasingly clear that adolescent brains are not yet fully mature in regions and systems related to higher-order executive functions such as impulse control, planning ahead, and risk avoidance."<ref name=":20" />
== Criticism == There have been some critiques of the dual systems model<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pfeifer|first=Jennifer H.|last2=Allen|first2=Nicholas B.|date=June 2012|title=Arrested development? Reconsidering dual-systems models of brain function in adolescence and disorders|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume=16|issue=6|pages=322–329|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2012.04.011|issn=1879-307X|pmc=3711850|pmid=22613872}}</ref> purporting that: (1) there are too few studies to provide enough [[Empirical evidence|empirical]] support for the model; (2) empirical evidence are contrary to the model, namely that activation of the ventral affective or socioemotional system has been associated with [[Adaptive behavior|adaptive]] behavior and activation of the cognitive control system has been associated with [[Maladaptation|maladaptive]] functioning; and (3) the model is overly simplistic in its description of brain development. Respondents continue to assert the value in the dual systems model despite acknowledging that it is a simplified model of real-world behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Strang|first=Nicole M.|last2=Chein|first2=Jason M.|last3=Steinberg|first3=Laurence|date=2013-05-27|title=The value of the dual systems model of adolescent risk-taking|journal=Frontiers in Human Neuroscience|volume=7|doi=10.3389/fnhum.2013.00223|issn=1662-5161|pmc=3664310|pmid=23750132}}</ref>
Others have criticized the triadic model for a lack of evidence implicating the emotion processing systems (e.g., the amygdala) in risk-taking during adolescence.<ref name=":2" />

{{See also|Ecosystem|Biome}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2016}} [[File:BlueMarble-2001-2002.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Two views of the Earth from space.|The [[Earth]] has many diverse [[ecosystems]] and ecologicalsystem diversity. These are NASA composite images of the Earth: 2001 (left), 2002 (right), titled ''[[The Blue Marble]]''.]]
'''Ecosystem diversity''' deals with the variations in [[ecosystem]]s within a [[geographical location]] and its overall impact on human existence and the [[environmental impact|environment]].
Ecosystem diversity is a type of [[biodiversity]]. It is the variation in the [[ecosystems]] found in a region or the variation in ecosystems over the whole planet. Biodiversity is important because it clears out our water, changes out climate, and provides us with food. Ecological diversity includes the variation in both [[Terrestrial ecosystem|terrestrial]] and [[aquatic ecosystem]]s. Ecological diversity can also take into account the variation in the [[complexity]] of a [[biological community]], including the number of different [[ecological niche|niches]], the number of [[trophic level]]s and other ecological processes. An example of ecological diversity on a global scale would be the variation in ecosystems, such as [[desert]]s, [[forest]]s, [[grassland]]s, [[wetland]]s and [[ocean]]s. Ecological diversity is the largest scale of biodiversity, and within each ecosystem, there is a great deal of both [[Species diversity|species]] and [[genetic diversity]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Margaret|last= Cunningham|url=http://study.com/academy/lesson/what-is-biodiversity-definition-and-relation-to-ecosystem-stability.html|website=study.com|series= DSST Environment & Humanity: Study Guide & Test Prep |title=What is Biodiversity? - Definition and Relation to Ecosystem Stability|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|year=2009|chapter=Ecosystems|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=GVRL&sw=w&u=colu91149&v=2.1&it=r&id=GALE%7CCX3233900080&asid=ece573364e176588534845e3350339a7|title=Environmental Science: In context|series=In Context Series |volume=1|pages=242–246|publisher=Gale|location=Detroit|oclc=277051356|isbn=978-1-4103-3754-2 |editors=Brenda Wilmoth Lerner and K. Lee Lerner }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Purdy|first=Elizabeth|year=2012|chapter=Ecosystems|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=GVRL&sw=w&u=colu91149&v=2.1&it=r&id=GALE%7CCX4195600251&asid=1b9f7d7c752292d2c015aaaa651455a9|title=Encyclopedia of Global Warming & Climate Change|doi=10.4135/9781452218564 |pages=485–487|via=Gale Virtual Reference Library|isbn=978-1-4129-9261-9|editor=S. George Philander|volume= 1|edition= 2nd|location= Thousand Oaks, CA|publisher=SAGE Reference}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|year=2009|chapter=Ecosystem Diversity|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?tabID=T003&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R4&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=7&userGroupName=colu91149&inPS=true&sort=RELEVANCE&contentSegment=&prodId=GVRL&contentSet=GALE%7CCX3233900079&docId=GALE%7CCX3233900079&docType=GALE&u=colu91149&authCount=1#|title=Environmental Science: In Context|series=In Context Series |volume=1|pages=239–241|publisher=Gale|location=Detroit|oclc=277051356|isbn=978-1-4103-3754-2|editors=Brenda Wilmoth Lerner and K. Lee Lerner}}</ref>
== Impact ==
Diversity in the ecosystem is significant to human existence for a variety of reasons. Ecosystem diversity boosts the availability of [[oxygen]] via the process of [[photosynthesis]] amongst plant organisms domiciled in the habitat. Diversity In an aquatic environment helps in the [[water purification|purification of water]] by plant varieties for use by humans. Diversity increases plant varieties which serves as a good source for medicines and [[herb]]s for human use. A lack of diversity in the ecosystem produces an opposite result.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Naveh|first=Z.|date=1994-09-01|title=From Biodiversity to Ecodiversity: A Landscape-Ecology Approach to Conservation and Restoration|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1526-100X.1994.tb00065.x/abstract|journal=Restoration Ecology|language=en|volume=2|issue=3|pages=180–189|doi=10.1111/j.1526-100x.1994.tb00065.x|issn=1526-100X}}</ref>
== Examples == Some examples of ecosystems that are rich in diversity are: * [[Deserts]] * [[Forests]] * [[Large marine ecosystem]]s * [[Marine ecosystem]]s * [[Old growth forest]]s * [[Rainforest]]s * [[Tundra]] * [[Coral Reef]]s * [[Marine biology|Marine]]
== Ecosystem diversity as a result of evolutionary pressure == Ecological diversity around the world can be directly linked to the evolutionary and [[Evolutionary pressure|selective pressures]] that constrain the [[Diversity index|diversity]] outcome of the ecosystems within different [[Niche segregation|niches]]. [[Tundra|Tundras]], [[Rainforest|Rainforests]], coral reefs and [[deciduous forests]] all are formed as a result of [[Evolutionary pressure|evolutionary pressures]]. Even seemingly small evolutionary interactions can have large impacts on the diversity of the [[Ecosystem|ecosystems]] throughout the world. One of the best studied cases of this is of the honey bee's interaction with [[Flowering plant|angiosperms]] on every continent in the world except [[Antarctica|Antartica]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://animals.mom.me/continents-bees-not-found-5374.html|title=On What Continents Are Bees Not Found?|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en}}</ref>
In 2010 Robert Brodschneider, and Karl Crailsheim conducted a study about the health and nutrition in honey bee colonies, the study conducted focused on: overall colony health, adult nutrition, and [[larva]] nutrition as a function of the effect of [[Pesticide|pesticides]], [[Monoculture|monocultures]] and genetically modified crops to see if the anthropogenically created problems can have an effect pollination levels.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brodschneider|first=Robert|date=2010|title=Nutrition and health in Honey bees|url=https://www.apidologie.org/articles/apido/pdf/2010/03/m09120.pdf|journal=Apidologie|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The results indicate that human activity does have a role in the destruction of the fitness of the bee colony. The extinction or near extinction of these pollinators would result in many plants that feed humans on a wide scale, needing alternative pollination methods.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/12.000/www/m2015/2015/bee_tech.html|title=Mission 2015: Bee Technology|website=web.mit.edu|access-date=2018-11-30}}</ref> Crop pollinating insects are worth annually 14.6 billion to the [[Economy of the United States|US economy]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/5193-Decline-of-bees-forces-China-s-apple-farmers-to-pollinate-by-hand|title=Decline of bees forces China's apple farmers to pollinate by hand|website=www.chinadialogue.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> and cost to hand pollinate over insect pollination will cost an estimated 5,715-$7,135 per hectare additionally. Not only will there be a cost increase but also an decrease in colony fitness, leading to a decrease in genetic diversity, which studies have shown has a direct link to the long term survival of the honey bee colonies. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/06/130617111341.htm|title=Genetic diversity key to survival of honey bee colonies|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en}}</ref>
According to a study, there are over 50 plants that are dependent on bee pollination, many of these being key staples to feeding the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930020735/http://gears.tucson.ars.ag.gov/beeclass/Pollination.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=2007-09-30|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Another study conducted states that as a direct result of a lack of [[Plant diversity and evolution|plant diversity]], will lead to a decline in the bee population fitness, and a low bee colony fitness has impacts on the fitness of plant ecosystem diversity. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Science_News/2018/08/22/Plant-biodiversity-essential-to-bee-health/7391534949396/|title=Plant biodiversity essential to bee health|work=UPI|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en}}</ref> By allowing for bee pollination and working to reduce [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenically]] harmful footprints, bee pollination can increase flora growth genetic diversity and create a unique ecosystem that is highly diverse and can provide a habitat and niche for many other organisms to thrive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.onegreenplanet.org/animalsandnature/why-bees-are-important-to-our-planet/|title=Why Bees Are Important to Our Planet - One Green Planet|website=www.onegreenplanet.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Due to the evolutionary pressures of bees being located on six out of seven continents, there can be no denying the impact of [[Pollinator|pollinators]] on the ecosystem diversity. The [[pollen]] collected by the bees is harvested and used as an energy source for winter time, this act of collecting pollen from local plants also has a more important effect of facilitating the movement of genes between [[Organism|organisms]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Min|last2=Compton|first2=Stephen G.|last3=Peng|first3=Fo-En|last4=Zhang|first4=Jian|last5=Chen|first5=Xiao-Yong|date=2015-06-07|title=Movements of genes between populations: are pollinators more effective at transferring their own or plant genetic markers?|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4455804/|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|volume=282|issue=1808|doi=10.1098/rspb.2015.0290|issn=0962-8452|pmc=4455804|pmid=25948688}}</ref>
The new evolutionary pressures that are largely [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenically]] catalyzed can potentially cause wide spread collapse of ecosystems. In the north Atlantic sea, a study was conducted that followed the effects of the human interaction on surrounding ocean habitats. They found that in there was no [[habitat]] or [[trophic level]] that in some way was effected negatively by human interaction, and that much of the diversity of life was being stunted as a result.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lotze|first=Heike K.|last2=Milewski|first2=Inka|date=October 2004|title=TWO CENTURIES OF MULTIPLE HUMAN IMPACTS AND SUCCESSIVE CHANGES IN A NORTH ATLANTIC FOOD WEB|url=https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1890/03-5027|journal=Ecological Applications|language=en|volume=14|issue=5|pages=1428–1447|doi=10.1890/03-5027|issn=1051-0761}}</ref>

''''eSagu'''' is a web-based personalized agro-advisory system which uses [[Information Technology]] to solve the unscientific agricultural practices. Sagu means cultivation in [[Telugu language|Telugu]]-local language of [[Telangana]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telanganastateofficial.com/e-sagu-web-portal-for-farmers/ |location=Hyderabad, India | work=TSO | title=Farmers to educate through online in telangana| date=8 August 2015}}</ref> [[Andhra Pradesh]], the region in which the project started. E-Sagu means electronic cultivation. It exploits the advances in Information Technology to build a cost-effective agricultural information dissemination system to disseminate expert agriculture knowledge to the farming community to improve the crop productivity.
It is a joint research project of [[Media lab asia]][http://www.medialabasia.in] and [[IIIT Hyderabad]]
